text: cash is one of those things that's
pretty hard to resist it's got that
buttery flaky crust if you used a
regular pie crust it's too flaky and the
filling would seep under the crust and
that's definitely not what you want you
don't want to soggy bottom to your
quiche and I've made this crust extra
sturdy by adding some eggs and that is
really the key one in 3/4 cups of flour
I'm going to scoop and level quarter cup
a half a cup and one okay then one
teaspoon of coarse salt and 1 stick of
cold unsalted butter cut into cubes
now we'll pulse this just to make some
coarse crumbs one whole egg one egg yolk
this is really going to add richness and
structure to the crust and then 3
tablespoons of ice water again cold
ingredients okay mix this up I like to
pour this straight on to the dry
ingredients I find if I pour it through
the feed tube I have a tendency to over
mix the dough quickly get the top on and
start pulsing and I'm stopping just as
it's starting to clump together
so all these crumbs come right onto a
piece of plastic pull up the corners and
press together this is a very easy way
to not overwork your dough I like to
make sure it's round because then it's
half way there when I start rolling okay
so this goes into the refrigerator for
30 minutes up to 4 hours okay flour the
surface nice even coat and then flour
the top of the dough this I want to roll
out to about 14 inches to fit into the
springform so this recipe makes enough
for one 9-inch springform deep-dish
quiche or you could make it in two pie
plates
great 14 inches just going to roll up
the dough on the pin and then drape it
over the 9-inch springform so at this
point you don't want to stretch the
dough you want to fit it inside press
these folds into the walls of the pan
this is going to give us a nice sturdy
crust just trim off that excess and this
now goes into the freezer for 30 minutes
to get nice and firm before we put it in
the oven okay this is our frozen dough
it's nice and firm we need to line it
with some parchment and fill it with
dried beans or pie weights this will
help keep the base flat while it's
baking and you can reuse these over and
over so this crust goes into the oven at
400 degrees with a sheet pan set below
the rack that the quiche goes on for 20
minutes this is called the blind bake
this is when we're going to get the
crust all the way cooked through before
we add the filling so 20 minutes with
the beans in we'll take out the beans
and bake for another 12 to 15 minutes
till we get a nice golden brown crust
you
